results.headline: An Iranian Village Mob and a Wife’s Execution

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Stoning of Soraya M.

results.summary_short: “The Stoning of Soraya M.” thoroughly blurs the line between high-minded outrage and lurid torture-porn.

results.headline: My Kidney, My Life: Siblings in a Tough Spot

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Sister's Keeper

results.summary_short: The prospect of a child’s death is so awful that to broach it in a movie or a book requires a special measure of caution and sensitivity. Or so you might think.

results.headline: Dad Is Distracted by Life, Work and a Motherless 10-Year-Old Daughter

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quiet Chaos

results.summary_short: “Quiet Chaos” demonstrates that the sad-dad melodrama is a global (or at least a midlevel European art film) phenomenon.

results.headline: May-December Love Can Lead to Discontent

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chéri

results.summary_short: Decadence perfumes the deceptively tragic story of “Chéri.”

results.headline: Invasion of the Robot Toys, Redux

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen

results.summary_short: In “Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen,” the director Michael Bay’s subject is as blatant and consistent as his cluttered mise-en-scène.

results.headline: In the Beginning, God Created Yuks

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Year One

results.summary_short: Harold Ramis’s “Year One” is a thoroughly, sometimes gaggingly broad and sly conceptual laugh-in.

results.headline: Kvetch Your Enthusiasm

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Whatever Works

results.summary_short: My problem with “Whatever Works” is not that the premise is a wee bit familiar. Rather, it’s that the delivery is off.

results.headline: Ticked Off

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Under Our Skin

results.summary_short: “Under Our Skin” is scary enough to make the faint of heart decide never to venture into the woods or to lie on the grass again without protective covering.

results.headline: From the Corporate Jungle to Wild Alaska: Taming the Savage Boss

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Proposal

results.summary_short: Like most Hollywood romantic comedies these days, “The Proposal” is all about bringing a woman to her knees.

results.headline: Figures Made of Clay in an Imaginary World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of $9.99

results.summary_short: “$9.99” uses an extraordinary technique to bring the Israeli writer Etgar Keret’s world to life.

results.headline: Weaned on the Thug’s Life, but Pulled Toward Grander Ambitions

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Narrows

results.summary_short: Until it implodes with preposterous plot manipulations, “The Narrows” can be appreciated as the film equivalent of a reasonably palatable pasta dish.

results.headline: Consumption and Extinction

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The End of the Line

results.summary_short: “The End of the Line” subverts our ancient faith in the ocean as an inexhaustible resource.

results.headline: Nipping at Your Nose

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dead Snow

results.summary_short: Chomp-chomp, zip-zip go the Nazi zombies in “Dead Snow,” a self-consciously outlandish horror flick.

results.headline: A Documentary Filmmaker Who Turned the Camera on Himself

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Windmill Movie

results.summary_short: “The Windmill Movie” is a version of the autobiography of Richard P. Rogers that might have been.

results.headline: Stand Clear of the Closing Doors

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Taking of Pelham 123

results.summary_short: “The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3,” an energetic updating of the 1974 mass transit thriller, takes account of how much the character of New York has changed.

results.headline: French Political Thriller as Allegory, but There’s a Bazooka in the Closet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Le Combat dans l'ile

results.summary_short: “Le Combat dans l’Île” is the latest in what seems to be an endless parade of obscure or half-forgotten French films to find their way to Film Forum.

results.headline: A Musician’s Passion
results.display_title: Youssou N'Dour: I Bring What I Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Youssou N'Dour: I Bring What I Love

results.summary_short: In this documentary portrait of the Senegalese superstar Youssou N’Dour, we get to groove to his crisp, soaring, polyrhythmic music.

results.headline: Portrait of an Activist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sex Positive

results.summary_short: Daryl Wein’s documentary about the onetime AIDS activist Richard Berkowitz is a polemic against societal amnesia.

results.headline: Parties and Pain

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last International Playboy

results.summary_short: Grown men behaving like emotional infants are seldom fun to be around, a truism that “The Last International Playboy” does nothing to disprove.

results.headline: Planet Earth Is Blue and So Very Far Away

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moon

results.summary_short: “Moon,” presents a vision of life beyond Earth that emphasizes claustrophobia and loneliness.
